elements.label: Object Type
elements.description: Types of information

elements.label: Organization
elements.description: An established entity such as a university or company

elements.label: Member
elements.description: People who are verified members of a group or event

elements.label: Idea
elements.description: An idea or suggestion

elements.label: Place
elements.description: Places are locations of interest, geographical spots.

elements.label: Group
elements.description: A online or in-person community that you can join

elements.label: Solution
elements.description: Answers or fixes to problems

elements.label: Alliance for the Mystic River Watershed

elements.summary: The Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, one of America’s oldest tribes, shares its culture and history through a museum in Connecticut.
elements.description: The Mashantucket (Western) Pequot Tribal Nation is a federally recognized Indian tribe located at one of America’s oldest Indian reservations, Mashantucket, in Southeastern Connecticut.
elements.label: Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation

elements.summary: The Eastern Pequot Tribal Nation is a Connecticut-based Native American tribe descended from the Pequot people.
elements.description: The Eastern Pequot Tribal Nation is an American Indian tribe in southeastern Connecticut descended from the Pequot people who dominated southeastern New England in the seventeenth century. It is one of five tribes recognized by the state of Connecticut.(\[Wikipedia page]\(<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Pequot_Tribal_Nation>))
elements.label: Eastern Pequot Tribal Nation

elements.summary: An initiative fostering collaboration among the middle and lower Connecticut River watershed communities.
elements.description: A collaboration of people in the middle and lower Connecticut River watershed.
elements.label: Connecticut River Valley Bioregioning Collaborative

elements.summary: BioFi is a collective supporting bioregions in building Bioregional Financing Facilities to link financial resources with regenerative efforts.
elements.description:
**Bioregional Finance for Planetary Regeneration (BioFi)**
We are a collective supporting bioregions to design, build, and implement Bioregional Financing Facilities that connect financial resources and regenerators.
elements.label: BioFi

elements.summary: Regen Foundation supports diverse communities with technologies and ideas for ecological, economic, and human well-being.
elements.description: Regen Foundation supports diverse communities with ideas and technologies which integrate ecological, economic, and human well-being.
elements.label: Regen Foundation

elements.description: Tribally owned and operated since it opened on Aug. 11, 1998, the Museum brings to life the story of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation. It serves as a major resource on the histories and cultures of Native Americans in the northeast and on the region’s rich natural history.
elements.label: Mashantucket Pequot Museum

elements.summary: Foundation House is a local resource for events and discussions on critical social issues.
elements.description: Foundation House is committed to becoming a local resource providing a safe place for robust convenings, workshops, lectures, and events. We will initiate conversations on compelling topics, and welcome outside groups who seek to do the same.
elements.label: Foundation House

elements.summary: r3.0 promotes global redesign for resilience and regeneration through open-source recommendations across various sectors.
elements.description:
**r3.0 - Redesign for Resilience & Regeneration**
"r3.0 promotes Redesign for Resilience and Regeneration. As a global common good not-for-profit platform, r3.0 crowdsources open recommendations for necessary transformations across diverse fields and sectors, in response to the ecological and social collapses humanity is experiencing, in order to achieve a thriving, regenerative and distributive economy and society."
elements.label: r3.0

elements.summary: Soil & Climate Initiative offers a farm-to-shelf regenerative agriculture program with third-party verification options.
elements.description:
Bring Soil & Climate Health to Market
Soil & Climate Initiative is a holistic farm-to-shelf regenerative agriculture program with options for third-party verification.
elements.label: Soil & Climate Initiative

elements.summary: A map visualizing people collaborating to co-create funding ecosystems for regenerative projects.
elements.description: A social system map of people gathering to co-create funding ecosystems for regeneration.
elements.label: CoFundEco

elements.summary: Exploring a Knowledge Commons to support regenerative efforts in the northeastern bioregion.
elements.description:
Purpose: To explore possibilities for a Knowledge Commons  in support of an evolving ecosystem of shared services for regenerative efforts in the northeast bioregion(s) (DRAFT)

A commons includes both a shared resource and a community that stewards it and keeps both its resources and its community alive and well.  The same is true of a Knowledge Commons, for example, the Regenerative Knowledge Commons community and its  [Regenerative Knowledge Commons Wiki](https://rkc.communitiesforfuture.org/index.php/Main_Page#tab=RKC_Subsystems) that it created and stewards.
Note, however, that a knowledge commons resource may not include only electronic or paper, but also may include other sources and forms of information and knowing, including human and more than human.

In forming and evolving the community responsible for defining, developing and stewarding the NE Bioregional Knowledge Commons, the patterns catalogued in \[Triad of commoning Patterns]\(<https://kumu.io/rmattlage/the-triad-of-commoning#triad-of-commoning?focus=%23the-triad-of-commoning%20out%202>) will prove an instructive resource derived from studying successful commons across the globe.

Any commons will never be a complete solution for all the information/knowledge needs of a community.  
Indeed, it may be the case that much/most of the knowledge resides in the region's humans, more-than-humans, places and ecosystems, and that the Knowledge Commons just provides one of many of the doorways to those knowledges.  Further, just as a bioregion is a commons which probably consists of an interlinked federation of commons serving different domains and communities, so too will its Knowledge Commons likely be an interlinked federation of knowledge commons, each one serving its community. 

Underlying technologies are evolving and not yet mature for these purposes.  We will continue to explore alternatives, both for interactive front ends such as this Kumu prototype and for core "information management" technologies such as Wikis, Google Sheets, \[sumApp]\(<https://greaterthanthesum.com/sumapp/>), etc. The community will need to evolve its adoption of technologies as they, and our needs, evolve.
elements.label: NE Bioregional Knowledge Commons

elements.summary: Our mission is to engage the community in addressing the climate emergency. We organize, educate, take direct action, and implement practical, ecological solutions for a just transition to a thriving, regenerative economy.
elements.label: Center for an Ecology-Based Economy

elements.summary: The Regenerative Knowledge Commons is an open-source, wiki-based platform for collectively generating knowledge about regenerative commoning.
elements.description: **The Regenerative Knowledge Commons** (RKC)! is an open-source, wiki-based commons for collectively (re)generating knowledge, understanding and even wisdom, perhaps, around regenerative commoning!
elements.label: Regenerative Knowledge Commons

elements.summary: A project focused on bioregional food and biomaterials economies, emphasizing equity and ecological health.
elements.description: ... working on infrastructure for bioregional food and biomaterials economy, organizing for decades with farmers, builders, and designers across the region to do this in an equitable and ecologically healthy way.
elements.label: Northeast BioEconomy Initiative

elements.summary: A project exploring the establishment of a Bioregional Learning Center at the Sirius Ecovillage and Education Center.
elements.description: An initiative to explore creating a \[Bioregional Learning Center]\(<https://medium.com/@joe_brewer/what-is-a-bioregional-learning-center-b5c3f3b59222>) at the Sirius Ecovillage and Education Center
elements.label: Sirius BLC

elements.summary: Forests of the Northeast explores regenerative bioregioning across the northeastern USA and parts of Canada.
elements.description: The Forests of the Northeast (FoNE) is an initiative to explore regenerative bioregioning in the northeastern USA (and Canada?)
elements.label: Forests of the Northeast

elements.summary: The Dawnlands Bioregioning Collective is exploring bioregional financing for the Northeastern US and parts of Canada.
elements.description:
A group drawn together by an interest in developing Bioregional Financing Facilities in the Northeastern US and adjacent parts of Canada.
Provisionally renamed:** Dawnlands Bioregioning Collective** (10.24.24)
elements.label: Northeast Bioregional Finance (Ne BioFi)

elements.summary: BioFi has held gatherings with regional initiatives to explore developing a Bioregional Financing Facility.
elements.description: Three gatherings " ... built on engagement between **BioFi **and a number of different initiatives in the bioregion that had expressed interest in piloting the development of a bioregional financing facility (BFF) for the bioregion.
elements.label: Forests of the Northeast Bioregional Regeneration Forum
